stem: The nurse is evaluating a client for hypercortisolism. Highlight the physical assessment findings that are classic indicators of Cushing's syndrome.
passage: The client is a 38-year-old female who has been taking high-dose prednisone for systemic lupus erythematosus. Upon assessment, the nurse notes [rounding of the facial profile] and a [prominent fat pad on the upper back]. The client's [abdomen is protuberant] with presence of [wide, purple striae]. The [skin on the client's arms is thin and translucent] with multiple [ecchymoses]. A check of the vital signs shows [blood pressure is 158/94 mmHg]. The client notes [significant muscle weakness] in the thighs and [excessive facial hair growth]. A random blood glucose is [142 mg/dL].

rationale.correct: Cushing's syndrome results from excessive cortisol. Classic signs include 'moon face' (facial rounding), 'buffalo hump' (fat pad on upper back), truncal obesity (protuberant abdomen), purple striae, thin/fragile skin, ecchymoses (easy bruising), hypertension (from sodium/water retention), muscle wasting/weakness (especially in extremities), hirsutism (excessive hair), and hyperglycemia.
rationale.incorrect: The age, sex, and history of lupus/prednisone use are relevant context/causes but are not themselves physical assessment findings characteristic of the syndrome.
rationale.clinicalPearls: Iatrogenic Cushing's (from corticosteroid use) is the most common cause. When symptoms occur from an ACTH-secreting pituitary tumor, it is called Cushing's Disease.
rationale.questionTrap: Be careful to distinguish striae in Cushing's (purple/wide) from those in pregnancy or weight gain (usually silvery/white).

reviewUnits.heading: Cushing's Assessment
reviewUnits.body: Remember 'STRESSED': Skin fragile, Truncal obesity, Round face/Reproductive issues, Ecchymosis/Elevated BP, Striae, Sugar high, Excessive hair, Dorsocervical fat pad (Buffalo hump).

answerBreakdown.content: The identified evidence represents objective clinical markers of physiological instability.
